Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: St. Elias Erosion and Tectonics Project (STEEP)
Award.AbstractNarration: This project provides funds for a two-year renewal of the St. Elias Erosion-tectonics Project (STEEP). STEEP is a 9 institution, multidisciplinary study of the St. Elias orogen in southern Alaska that involves researchers examining the system from the outcrop to lithosphere scale. To date, STEEP has produced 17 papers with another 9 submitted or nearing submission, sponsored 71 abstracts, will have matriculated 5 masters and 4 Doctoral students by Spring 2010, and fundamentally changed our understanding of Alaskan tectonics and the interaction of tectonics and climate in mountain building. The renewal funds will be used for: 1) final processing and interpretation of some key datasets that were not acquired until year 5 of the project including the marine seismic survey (ship delays) and reoccupation of key GPS sites (weather problems in 2008); and 2) a complete integration of results which was not possible until now due to these delays. A complete integration and synthesis of these superb datasets has the potential to be transformative in our understanding of how crustal structure and tectonic forces interact with Earth surface processes of glacial erosion and sedimentary transport to grow a mountain range and a massive continental shelf.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Glacial erosion in the St. Elias area is similar to the river erosion in the Himalayas in that it is capable of maintaining and deepening valleys at approximately the same rates that collision of tectonic plates is displacing deep rocks upwards. This balance between two vigorous processes – erosion and tectonics- causes the mountain range to organize into a larger cooperative system through a series of feedbacks. Earth responds to the high rates of material removal through erosion by flowing into the region of high erosion. This results in weakening of the near surface Earth as hotter, weaker rocks are brought up from depth, raising the Earth surface, intercepting more atmospheric moisture which produces greater glacial activity.  This series of positive feedbacks produces extreme topographic relief of the St Elias region of southeast Alaska.

 

Another feature of coupling among tectonic and glacial activity occurs through the influences of ice sheets with very large earthquakes. Because southeast Alaska is at the seismically active confluence of the two large tectonic plates, Pacific and North America, where one of the largest earthquakes ever recorded has occurred, the mechanical effect on seismicity of glacier changes has significant societal relevance. To investigate the role of the change of large glacial masses on earthquakes in this seismically active region, we used the highest resolution climate model for southeast Alaska currently available to provide input for an ice sheet model during the Last Glacial Maximum ( @ 18,000 years ago) and then examined the manner in which the upper 100km of Earth in this active, three-dimensional zone of plate convergence responded to the changing ice loads.  With the high resolution model capable of delineating individual glacial drainages, our coupled model predicts high strain release (~earthquake activity) in the same area where very large earthquakes have occurred (see the figures below).

 

During this grant, we have reached out to scientific, educational and broader communities through publications and presentations at major international conferences and at local workshops. In addition, we have continued to develop and expand the publicly available website for viewing climate reanalysis datasets funded in part by STEEP funds. See:  http://cci-reanalyzer.org/.  This project has partially or completely funded one MS graduate student and two undergraduate students and provided opportunities for travel, field work, exposure to national and international workshops. In addition, these students have had the opportunity to become familiar with the basic tools of large scale numerical computation of earth systems including 3D finite element techniques, mesoscale modeling of the atmosphere, data visualization and ice sheet modeling. The MS student, L. Wheeler has presented her work at AGU, NSF-funded workshops, IGNS- New Zealand and has been awarded an NSF EAPSI Fellowship for travel and research in New Zealand.
